name: TIME - 2014 Printable Calendar - (red and black) - UK/EU or US DATE FORMAT
description:
This 2014 Printable Calendar is ready for download. With 12 thoughtful and humorous quotes about Time by different wits and writers from Einstein to Dr. Seuss! Easy on the ink, this makes a perfect gift for under £10 for a friend, colleague or family member – a great last-minute gift. Great for walls, pin or magnet boards, desks and a stylish adornment to the fridge!

***Covers January 2014 to December 2014. (also includes December 2013)***
THE MONTHLY QUOTES: JANUARY: Time is what prevents everything from happening at once (Albert Einstein) FEBRUARY: When time is reduced to linear progress, it is emptied of presence. (John O’Donohue ) MARCH: Everywhere is within walking distance if you have the time. (Steven Wright) APRIL: Yesterday is but today’s memory and tomorrow is today’s dream. (Kahlil Gibran) MAY: Nature does not hurry, yet everything is accomplished. (Lao Tzu) JUNE: Your time is limited, so don’t waste it living someone else’s life. (Steve Jobs) JULY: Life is like an ice-cream cone, you have to lick it one day at a time. (Charles M. Schulz) AUGUST: If the future did not exist now, how could we journey toward it? (Gene Wolfe) SEPTEMBER: There’s never enough time to do all the nothing you want. (Bill Watterson) OCTOBER: By looking far into space we are also looking far back into time. (Carl Sagan) NOVEMBER: You’re only as young as the last time you changed your mind. (Timothy Leary) DECEMBER: How did it get late so soon? It's night before it’s afternoon. (Dr. Seuss)
You receive a Hi-Res PDF (suitable for home & copy centres) within 48 hours of payment (usually sooner). INSTRUCTIONS: Simply print out the 9 page, letter-sized PDF with 2 months per page, and cut each page down the middle (using the faint dotted line as a guide). For best results use card stock, but you can also use any good printer paper.
US Calendar PAPER SIZE: 8.5 x 11" CALENDAR SIZE: 5.5 x 8.5" OR UK/EU Calendar PAPER SIZE: (A4) 210 x 297mm CALENDAR SIZE: (A5) 148 x 210mm *** The UK/EU Calendar starts with Monday on the left ***
INCLUDES AS SHOWN: ♥ January 2013 to December 2013 monthly calendars ♥ A cover (for giving as a gift) ♥ Extra pages where you can write your NOTES / TO DO list as well as BIRTHDAY / DATES TO REMEMBER lists
© Melissa Alaverdy (THINGS THAT SING). All rights reserved. You can print the digital files for yourself and gift it to someone (in printed form only). You are not allowed to redistribute the printed or digital files in any way. Mass production and commercial use of this design is not allowed. This includes, but is not limited to, sharing, selling, reselling, and altering. If you are interested in purchasing a commercial license, please contact me.

name: Kokopelli Flute Player TOTE BAG
description:
"You can't wake a person who is pretending to be asleep" This Navajo quote is a gem and when I came across it, it repeated on me in a lovely, lyrical way. The Kokopelli flute player is an ancient symbol found on canyon walls and ancient pottery – a fertility deity who has been revered by some South Western Native American cultures – and presides over childbirth and agriculture. He is also a trickster god and represents the spirit of music.

name: BACKPACK - Kokopelli Flute Player
description:
"You can't wake a person who is pretending to be asleep" This Navajo quote is a gem and when I came across it, it repeated on me in a lovely, lyrical way. The Kokopelli flute player is an ancient symbol found on canyon walls and ancient pottery – a fertility deity who has been revered by some South Western Native American cultures – and presides over childbirth and agriculture. He is also a trickster god and represents the spirit of music.

100% natural organic cotton heavyweight canvas backpack with double shoulder straps, double tie with quick release fastening, hidden wallet holder with zip on back. Heat transfer printed.

name: Khasi Tribal (plum/turquoise) - 20x20cm
description:
Inspired by and adapted from a detail on a pre-20th century Khasi tribal poncho, North East India. The majority of the Khasis live in Meghalaya (with small populations in Bangladesh and Assam), and have been granted a protective status called 'Scheduled Tribe', recognized by the Indian constitution. Khasi culture is rich in folklore, with a story behind most of the names of hills, mountains, rivers, waterfalls, flowers, birds and animals.
